social_posts.post_text:
Scientists are engineering herpes to kill cancer. Say what???

The last 15 years of cancer innovation have followed the path of boosting the immune system to survive longer, become more powerful, or receive assistance in seeking and destroying the tumours. The most popular therapies being employed at present are Nobel Prize-winning checkpoint inhibitors, or engineering patients’ T cells to seek and destroy tumours. But in this recent study, cancer-killing viruses are being used to give the immune system an advantage to kill tumours.

Herpes, which is an oncolytic virus, seeks out tumours to infect and multiply within. This causes the tumour to burst, directing immune cells to this area, where they learn how to seek out and destroy other tumours. This early-stage phase I trial shows promising results in genetically modifying a herpes virus strain, HSV-1, to fight advanced cancers.

Once again, science is now making the once incurable, curable.

This post is a paid collaboration between myself and @weareunsensible , who brought this scientific study to life through their amazing artwork. You can find the full breakdown of this study on their website

“You don’t look like a scientist”
“Sex sells, you should play off being an attractive scientist”

Because apparently scientists are dishevelled, unattractive people. Have you seen my scicomm friends on here? 

I’ve been told many times to play on the whole being a half decent looking scientist thing because that will grow my following. 

 But I’m building a community with you guys based on science and data alone. Science doesn’t need a poster girl or guy. There’s so many insane breakthroughs happening to save yours and those you love lives right now. 

Gene therapy along with many other techs are saving those with once incurable illnesses. That’s way sexier than a thirst trap. 

👉🏼 FOLLOW ME FOR SCIENCE CONTENT 📲

👩🏻‍🔬The doctor of fixing your immune system / your mess will see you now.  I had to..

🧪 I’m being serious here, but if you ask every immunologist you know (legit ones please, not the quacks on here 💰) what’s one implementable thing you can do to support your immunity, they will say stress management as the number one tool. Yes there are others but stress is THE most important.

🧬 I know this may be easier said than done and some stressors can’t be removed, like being in school, having young kids or going through a rough patch at work during this climate. 

💫 But the best thing you can do, practically, is learn to deal with your stress. Therapy, throwing weight around in the gym or going for a run, being with wholesome friends and not isolating yourself… therapy… did I mention that already? 

💣 Stress is a time bomb on your immune cells. It literally suppresses your immunity, changes the characteristics of certain immune cells and makes them ill-equipped to deal with infections. For chronic illness warriors, stress will struggle to keep your virus like herpes or EBV under control, will struggle to keep your autoimmune cells behave themselves. And stress will set your immune cells as the losing team against potential cancer cells. 

😱 Think I’m being dramatic? No, look back on situations in your life where you’ve been overwhelmed and 💥, disease flare or bed bound with a bug 🦠.

🧐 So:
🔹 Find your therapy, or actually get therapy 
🔹 Cut back on what doesn’t serve you
🔹 Pamper yourself if you’ve had a stressful week
🔹 Block his number.

Your immunologist xox 

#immunology #immunesystem #scicomm #healthadvice #immunesupport #immunity #immunologist #chronicillness #chronicwarrior #autoimmune #autoimmunity #autoimmunewarrior

As if it needed to do anything else but anyway… 

💪🏼 Your immune cells don’t just fight infection and cancer; they also have roles in wound healing and tissue repair, so it’s no surprise that they’ve got some not so redundant roles in your muscles ! 

🏋🏻‍♀️ IL-13 is a cytokine, which is a fancy way of saying a signalling molecule released by immune cells so they can talk and influence each other. 

👟 IL-13 is typically involved in the T-helper 2 cell response which is the arm activated against parasites but also in allergies! 

💫 But, also all the wound and tissue healing I mentioned above !

🏃‍♀️ Here, the immune cells (ILC2s) in your muscles release IL-13 that mediate these effects. Please note that in this beautiful paper in Science, they looked at IL-13 knock out mice and humans too. Humans too have more circulating IL-13 after endurance exercise. 

This specific paper ID is here, but this just adds more to what we know and confirms the important role of immune cells and fitness / gains ! 

PMID: 32355002

Your immunologist xox

For The UK system, you do not automatically go into your defense (or Viva) having passed. Whilst your professor should never send you in to fail, you have 4 possible outcomes:
🇬🇧 Pass with major corrections to the thesis
🇬🇧Pass with minor corrections to the thesis. This is the most common outcome. 
🇬🇧 A Fail, it’s rare but I have seen it happen to someone. Execute more experiments before re-writing and re-submission. 
🇬🇧 Pass with zero corrections. Also rare.

💫 My story: My viva was during the pandemic, so it was on Zoom, for FOUR hours on zoom. I passed with zero corrections, this was my victory story.

🧐 How can the same happen to you (assuming you don’t have an egotistical professor that wants to make you suffer for no reason but academia)? 

🧪 Read your examiners papers because they will ask questions in relation to their field as this is what they know best. Write examples of how their work may pave questions to yours.

🧪 Have a justification for why your story unfolded the way it did. This means have a solid reason why you performed each experiment that you did. The answers “my PI told me so”, “we ran out of time”, “we ran out of funding” do not fly for a Viva.

🧪 Know your statistical tests and why you chose these. The answer “GraphPad Prism suggested the Mann-Whitney” is not acceptable.

🧪 If you did in vivo, be prepared for answers on your sample sizes. And “we didn’t have enough mice” won’t fly.

🧪 If you don’t know the answer to something, DO NOT BS! Instead, reply with “I do not know the answer to that, but I can try and guess based on what I know about ABC”.

🧪 Know your field well. My PhD was focused on Tregs, but I made sure to know my B cell biology very well.

🧪 Know what’s in your thesis very well, if they pick out a paragraph on a random page and ask you to discuss that citation, know what the paper is about because you included it after all…

🧬 Finally, enjoy it. It was hot seat grilling for me, but it was an incredibly joyful experience. You get to show off your hard work and defend it to the death, because no one knows better about your work than you. 

Good luck you champ 🤍 

Your immunologist xox

Hey guys ! Myth busting post number 1, finally !

Let’s talk “Immune Boosters”!

And let’s start with vitamin C! Whilst it does benefit some immune cells notably due to ROS and it’s anti oxidant properties protecting immune cells, there are gaps in mechanistic data and we just need further clarification on fully elucidating it’s role on different immune cell types.

Swipe left, happy reading !

Your immunologist xox 

#vitaminc #immunebooster #immunity

Next up on the Pokédex, a new PokeImmune card for you to collect !

🥷 Your immune system is made up of different fighters each with their own strengths and weaknesses kind of like an army…. 
What if there was an easier way to ID them? Hey, kinda like a Pokémon card ? 🙈

🤓 I introduce you to the Cytotoxic, or CD8, T cell! With this series, I launch the Adaptive Immune Series 🔥🔥

💣 I introduce you to your number 1 assassin of your immune system. The Aragorn of your armies, the Luke Skywalker of your intergalactic wars, the Ironman of the Avengers (k this one can be debated 🤷🏻‍♀️).
Point is, the CD8 T cell is your main killer, and goes through a specialised education system where it’s taught how to engage before an attack and who to kill specifically (i.e. yourself versus something foreign). CD8 T cells are the fancier NK cells that take longer to develop but are more precise, potent and develop memory.

☢️ CD8 T cells also do other things like Release inflammatory mediators (called cytokines) that instruct and engage other cells during the attack, but wanted to focus on their killing power here.

Virus or cancer, dispatch the CD8 assassins 🥷. 

💫 Over the weeks the Pokédex (yes me) will release more PokeImmune cards to educate you on Immunology !

Your slightly weird immunologist xox 

#scicomm #instascience #immunology #immunity #immunecells #learnwithme

Your CrossFitting immunologist is releasing this after doing Murph on Monday and taking the rest of the week off 🫠. Or because she has boundaries in resting, much like you should 🥹. 

A number of people have asked me this question as per my post to which the answer is simple: 
🔹 it isn’t clear what is the best modality - one thing I left out on this post is the age ranges assessed for such studies are just so varied 
🔹some of these analysis methods wouldn’t be the top choice by immunologists, but then again….
🔹 does it matter? Both show critical benefits to your immunity longterm.

But maybe the powerlifters and runners want to debate their style is best for their immune system. I can’t answer that, combine both, like CrossFit? 🫠 🍿🍿🍿

Your sore immunologist xox

I often get questions from you guys on how many proof of concept drugs or rather potential drug candidates actually make it as far as clinical trials?

🧪 Having worked at 2 Biotech start ups and seeing my first literally built from the ground up, I feel like I’ve gained a unique perspective here. 

💰 Is it really money that dermines this? Well mostly and you cannot blame investors or pharmaceuticals for the reasons I describe in this video.

🧐 Filling an unmet need or levelling up next to competition can make or break decisions from investors. If they’re going to fork out 10s of millions into a platform that could fail at Phase I due to safety issues is extremely risky. But if you can demonstrate your tech fills a desperate gap and has an edge over what’s out there (if any….) then, the 💰 may be put in. 

📈 This is when strategic considerations are made. It’s brutally harsh, but perhaps it’s harder to invest in a patient-specific cell therapy product for autoimmune diseases like type 1 diabetes or rheumatoid arthritis which can cost six figures per patient and over 100 million to get to clinic… when we have low cost options like insulin or Anti TNF options for the latter.
⏰  But the need for just something to work for pancreatic cancer (as there really is little) … that’s where the risks are more likely to be taken. 

👩🏻‍⚖️ But say you get the funding, you then submit an Investigational New drug application to your country’s regulatory body. For the US, I mentioned FDA, but for countries in Europe it’s the EMA, and the U.K. it’s the MHRA.

👩🏻‍⚖️ They come back with a list of questions to consider from R&D, process development, manufacturing, quality control and clinical monitoring that you need to have ironed out. From a regulatory, compliance stand point. 

🤝 But most importantly, you have to demonstrate to the best of your knowledge, that your drug should be safe before entering phase I.

🚨 Of course, you never know this until you actually begin a Phase I trial and begin dose escalation for safety. From then on, well, it’s a milestone you’ve reached this point….

Did you learn something new? Comment below 👇🏼👇🏼

Your immunologist xox

#biotech

Hi, immunologist back to debunk another fad. 
Okay autophagy isn’t a fad but the obsession to stimulate it without real human data is a bit peculiar to me. 

Autophagy is biology’s vacuum system, or recycling system. It’s absolutely imperative and if autophagy is inhibited in some way, it leads to copious problems and even death. The importance of autophagy is so clear especially in the neuro context.

The health and wellness industry are also keen to maximise autophagy for both health and longevity. So there’s lots of podcasts and videos out there explaining autophagy and how fasting can stimulate it. 

But this is important to remember : autophagy is also bad news in cancer. Groups are investigating ways to selectively inhibit autophagy in cancer cells in a targeted manner. 

Following suit from that, there are no human studies investigating the optimal fasting regimen (we can almost call this “dose”) to trigger autophagy. It’s too challenging to equate mouse work here to humans. 

I guess my biggest take away for you is that there are nuances when it comes to facts such as “fasting stimulates autophagy”. Yes it does, but it’s also unknown at what time point and for how long / and frequency to trigger autophagy. Individuals health statuses may mean fasting for longer periods is ill-advised. Plus the final caveat of this process which is the cancer promoting part. 

Be sensible, seek medical advice where necessary and practice a healthy lifestyle as much as you can.

Your immunologist xox

#autophagy #autophagyfast

⭐️ Now this was an exciting proof of concept published in the last weeks!!

👩🏻‍🔬 Researchers based in China had the aim of creating a drug for lung cancer 

🧪 The issue with chemotherapy like paclitaxel is the systemic toxicity, so the authors wanted to find a way to deliver chemotherapy directly to the cancer cells.

🧪 Taking advantage of CAR T cell therapy, which is a type of immunotherapy that has boomed the cancer space in the last 10 years, it works by isolating immune cells (T cells) and giving them a receptor  like a gps 🚗, driving the immune cells to the tumours . 

🧪 Now, lots of cells release little balls (called vesicles or exosomes) sometimes to communicate with other cells or to exert a functional effect. 

🧪 Fascinatingly, it’s been found that these CAR T cells also release little exosomes that still have that little gps 🚗 in tact!

🧪 This makes exosomes a super attractive option to deliver drugs! They’re tiny (nano sized), very stable and can go directly inside other cells. 

🧪 If you harvest exosomes from CAR T cells, that means you have these nano sized cargo able to go wherever it’s programmed to.

🧪 Sooo… what if you stick in some potent chemotherapy (like paclitaxel) in there?

💥 And that’s exactly what these authors did! But they even managed to turn it into an inhaler 🤯🤯!!!

💥  The teeny tiny CAR T derived exosomes that contain the paclitaxel were nebulised making it an inhalant.

🧬 The scientists genetically engineered T cells to express a receptor that targets an antigen expressed in the lungs. This is the gps.

🧬 They then harvested these exosomes from the CAR T cell Petri dishes . 

🧬 They then stuck paclitaxel into the exosomes using an ⚡️current to force it inside.

🧬 They then induced lung cancer in mice and gave them this magic ball drug as an inhalant…..

🐭 The weaponised exosome not only localised to the tumours in the mice, but reduced the cancer and prolonged the mouse survival with low toxicity ! They also reprogrammed the hostile fortress of cancer cells to breakdown! 

Here is the paper, PMID: 37308954

Epic research against cancer 🤩🤩 !!

Your immunologist xox

Hi IG friends! One of you messaged me recently asking about the legitimacy of detoxifying your body of mold and that immediately screamed 🚨 bs alert.

Look the link between mold and allergies / asthma is clear, but the crazy hype surrounding toxic black mold or toxic mold syndrome causing neurological damage is just not true. 

Unless if you’re immunocompromised you’re likely to not be impacted by mold exposure (minus the allergy bit!). Even if you have an already dysregulated immune system the potential impact of mold is still somewhat unclear / edging towards unlikely to exacerbating the problem. 

The key takeaway here is smell the bs 🚨, if someone talks about a protocol to detoxify your body of mold then they’re just wanting your money 💩

But seriously, mold is grim, get rid of it if you have it. 

Your immunologist xox

This thought came to me and I don’t think we talk about it enough. I really wanted to make a post to say industry is 1000x better for an individual’s well being over academia, which I whole heartedly believe is true. To some extent I also believe this for pushing science forward but this is up for debate. Knowledge for the sake of knowledge perhaps is on par between academia and industry. However, the speed and efficiency to bring proof of concept drugs from inception into patients , no doubt industry wins here. So if this is what you want to do, translational work and see the impact of a drug candidate into trials, industry is the way. 

And if your PI or anyone in academia accuses you of selling your soul if you want to exit and move into industry, well, they’re just bitter or trying to gaslight you to stay within that toxic system. Choose you babe 💅🏼.

Your immunologist xox

1️⃣ Researchers wanted to explore the significance of abnormal number of chromosomes in cancer cells. This is called aneuploidy. If most cancer cells have aneuploidy, perhaps there is a benefit for the cells survival and malignancy. Using impressive engineering tactics, this collab unveiled that 3 copies of chromosome 1q is needed for those particular cancer cells to progress. PMID:. 36711674

2️⃣ Investigators at Rutgers University enrolled mother-to-be’s in a  DBPC randomised study where they attempted to restore the bacterial balance in newborns born via C section, where they are not exposed to the birth canal microbiota during a normal delivery. They called this “vaginal seeding” by swabbing the C-section delivered babies with a swab of their mother’s vaginal fluids. Though with its limitations, the findings in this small study showed the newborns microbiome similar to vaginally delivered babies at the end point. PMID: 37074174

3️⃣ Canadian researchers measured different proteins in male sperm and seminal plasma to see if they could identify intact “fertile” sperm within males with non-obstructive azoospermia (NOA). These scientists managed to create a diagnostic to identify intact sperm in a far less invasive way using targeted proteomics and immunofluorescence, specifically identifying 2 proteins with potential. PMID: 37087050

4️⃣ A meta-analysis of 12 studies including 832 participants compared those who did HIIT before their operation to their fitness (i.e. no longer than 3 months out) and subsequent post operative outcome.  A wide of operations were included. Unsurprisingly, the findings supported including HIIT as a prehab before major surgery as this would reduce postoperative complications. PMID: 37389875

5️⃣ Part of the battle against cancer is some cells acquiring resistance to treatment. In this paper, researchers identified that commonly used lung cancer targeted therapies can induce A3A, an enzymatic response that sustains drug resistance in the cancer cells.  By targeting A3A, this may be a strategy to suppress or delay targeted lung cancer treatment resistance. PMID: 37407818

Your immunologist xox

Unless if you want to spend $40 on a box of tampons, or to have an excuse to bump into a celeb in Malibu, don’t go to Erewhon for Seamoss.

We have no in human data. We cannot extrapolate in vitro or even in Vivo data. 

I’m not diminishing it’s probable benefits but also be pragmatic - you obtain the same benefits in your greens and berries. It’s no magic cure. 

Or maybe it is, show me the in human data first 🤓.

Your immunologist xox

Living with a chronic illness such as autoimmunity or other immune related disorders can cause people to turn to those who promise a way out on social media like the Medical Medium whose just pure evil in my opinion. 

Some so-called health and wellness experts who graduated from a short 12 week crash course or Google University may claim they have secret answers that the medics or researchers don’t. The pandemic exacerbated this issue.

They will go far as to using tactics to scare people as it’s an almost algorithm-promoting method to go viral. Many accounts have exploded on here thanks to fear-mongering. 

Many have exploded from claiming to have a bullet-proof method for curing chronic illnesses.

The hyper awareness, the anxiety-fuelled response, the disappointment and desperation behind trying this method or cutting these foods out or trying these supplements…. ironically drives stress that flares chronic illnesses. 

My career is in the realm of curing the incurable. We don’t have the answers, so please start to clean up your social media from accounts who claim to know how to fix you if you spend $$$$ on their plan.

Your immunologist xox

Next up on the Pokédex, is a new PokeImmune card for you to collect but also, my baby 🤓😍😍! The cell type I have specialised in, so, the best immune cell ever duh!!

The Ditto, the Eevee and the Mew of your immune system !!! The ONLY pokeimmune to have 200x potency!

🥷 Your immune system is made up of different fighters each with their own strengths and weaknesses kind of like an army…. 
What if there was an easier way to ID them? Hey, kinda like a Pokémon card ? 🙈

🤓 I introduce you to the Regulatory T cell, or Treg! She belongs apart of the Adaptive Immune Response 🔥🔥 

🧬 Kind of like Eevee, Tregs evolve from different ways - from normal T helper cells in your body that shape shift into Tregs (ahem, Ditto); when developing within the thymus the baby T cell receives different signals as well as it having a slightly stronger reaction during its education process. The details of this aren’t totally ironed out yet!

🧘‍♀️I introduce you to THE pokeimmune responsible for suppressing the immune system. 
🧘‍♀️The pokeimmune that calls off the attack once the infection has been cleared. 
🧘‍♀️The pokeimmune responsible for preventing autoimmunity or at best, calming it down from getting worse 

☢️ The pokeimmune that fundamentally stops your own immune system from killing you. The General of the Immune system. The Mew of your immune system.

🚨 WARNING! Though this Pokeimmune is absolutely critical in your arsenal, YOU MUST EXERCISE CAUTION when cancer cells arise. Keep as far away as possible from cancer cells 🚨! It’s ability to suppress the immune system is one of the main weapons cancer manipulates to its advantage, to avoid attack from the rest of the immune system 🔔🔔

⚔️But Autoimmunity, organ transplant, allergies, dispatch this pokeimmune.

💫 Over the weeks the Pokédex (yes me) will release more PokeImmune cards to educate you on Immunology !

Your slightly weird immunologist xox 

#scicomm #instascience #immunology #immunity #immunecells #learnwithme

Finally I hope this answers some of your questions on what strategies scientists are exploring for curing autoimmune diseases ! 

This is literally the cell therapy landscape for autoimmunity ! The intricacies of genetic engineering like CRISPR, the debate on a CAR vs TCR T cell (or Treg!) therapy continues. 

For now, I’ve left the autoimmune space as I work in the cancer immunotherapy field but I still have a keen eye open to see how my previous company are doing as well as their competitors !! 

All in all, the science is impressive and we are moving mountains - no seriously, a lot of these are already in Phase I clinical trials for various autoimmune diseases.

This is the first post of many more on the autoimmune disease landscape, so stayed tuned on this page. 

Also helpful hint, pair this post with my set of Pokeimmune cards for you to learn more. I will be releasing MSC pokeimmune card this week! 

📲 Follow me for more science content!

Your immunologist xox

We are back with part 4 in our immunotherapy series! It’s been a long time coming and today we are going to discuss CANCER VACCINES!
. 
A vaccine, in general, contains materials called antigens to teach our bodies how to respond to potentially dangerous organisms in our environment. Basically, vaccines provide an instruction manual to our immune system.
.
For example, there are many preventative (prophylactic) cancer vaccines like the HBV and HPV vaccines that target viruses known to cause cancer. 
.
Our immune system has the ability to recognize foreign invaders (pathogens) as well as issues that may arise within our own tissues. In immunology this topic is called “self versus non-self recognition” and the mechanisms which govern how we respond to pathogens are quite different from how we respond to “self” errors.
.
As cancer cells develop, they accrue errors over time and make all sorts of antigens which could stimulate the immune system. Cancer cells are parts of ourselves and they often make the same antigens as their tissue of origin (which makes them challenging to recognize). However, because cancer cells are kinda messed up they can develop new antigens, or “neoantigens”.
.
Neoantigens can be weird variants of sugars, lipids, nucleic acids, and proteins. They can even exist in combinations where sugars are attached to proteins (glycoproteins)!
.
Neoantigens can be exploited for vaccine production. Although there are very few currently FDA approved cancer vaccines, there are many being investigated in clinical trials upon personalized approaches!
.
A recent study (PMID: 37165196) examined the use of personalized mRNA vaccines using similar technology as the SARS-CoV-2 vaccines. Basically, individual patient’s pancreatic tumor samples were removed and sequenced via whole genome sequencing to find neoantigens. Once neoantigens were determined, researchers developed personalized mRNA vaccines in as little as 9 weeks! Although these mRNA vaccines have a long way to go before being approved for treatment, cancer vaccines hold a lot of promise in treating human cancers of all types.
.
#immunotherapy #cancervaccine #cancerresearch #cancertreatment #nanotech

“Well all doctors are in an echo chamber anyway”

“It’s not your fault, you were just trained in the system they wanted you in”

“You’re a sheep, you’re blind, wake up and see the bigger picture” 

Sis, I’m a British scientist who has no political affiliation in the US (cos I can’t vote…) do you trust me now? 🥲

The pandemic has caused massive mistrust between the public and normal scientists like me. I can’t tell you how many times I’ve heard the above.

Your neighbourhood scientist may have appeared to change their minds or pivot their views, however the release of new information and data means new conclusions - this isn’t hypocrisy, this is science.

There’s also a reason why some of us have come on here to debunk TikTok trends, so-called wellness influencers who took a short course on a subject and claim to have a vast amount of understanding on a topic that takes years to master. 

It also takes a particular skill to sift through publications and tease out the articles that are well-executed and written - a skill you can only attain from going through academic or medical training as you are put in a position where you have no choice but to read thousands of papers to execute your own hypothesis. For example, the aspartame drama was a fantastic litmus test of who can science and who can’t.

Anyway, I’m back making reels 🤣. 

Your British-non-US-politically-affiliated-immunologist who has no agenda on here but to talk about immunology cos I’m kind of like a MASSIVE nerd.

Xxx

Hi team, I’ve never actually discussed with you guys why an “immune boosting” supplement isn’t so easy to conjure up. 

I have had people ask me to collaborate on their product that supposedly boosts NK cell activity and numbers like crazy and even if it were backed by in human data, I’d be rather concerned on the safety side of things.

Hopefully this quick , short post gives a simple explanation why!

FYI, I’m in the immunotherapy space right now trying to work through some of these challenges🤓. 

Your immunologist xox

Hey guys, I’ve gotten a lot of questions on whether endometriosis is autoimmune or not.

There’s two things we know: the immune system plays a role in the pathogenesis of endometriosis, and if you have endo there’s an association to having an autoimmune disease.
There’s no real surprises here 🤷🏻‍♀️, we’re dealing with a dysregulated immune system. 

But the “aha!” moments on classifying endometriosis as autoimmune got shot down quick when we’re debating whether the presence of autoantibodies proves it. Unfortunately this may just be likely due to the other immunological comorbidities.

There’s immune system involvement - which is super clear in endo - and then there’s a breakdown of immune tolerance, causing the immune system to confuse your own tissue as harmful and initiate the attack to kill. For now, we can’t see evidence of this. 

Who knows after more funding what we may unravel! But for now, we can recognise it is an inflammatory disease.

With that being said, using the same strategy as autoimmunity to treat endo, like immunosuppressants or some sort of biologics may be a topic of exploration for researchers! 

“Fun” fact about me,  I was diagnosed with adenomyosis when I was 21 because of the crippling cramps I would get. I also have Hashimotos disease. Anyway I was on the contraceptive pill to combat the adeno for 6 years until my infamous TIA “mini stroke”, and I had to come off them. It’s been a few years and so far no pains that take me out of commission completely 🤞🤞, though I know the same isn’t true for many on here 😔 xxx

Your immunologist xox

#endowarrior #endo #endometriosis

Next up on the Pokédex, a new PokeImmune card for you to collect !

🥷 Your immune system is made up of different fighters each with their own strengths and weaknesses kind of like an army…. 
What if there was an easier way to ID them? Hey, kinda like a Pokémon card ? 🙈

🤓 I introduce you to the Mesenchymal Stem Cell!🔥🔥 

🧬  Now you may be wondering how a Stem Cell has made its way into the Pokeimmune deck, but these nifty little shapeshifters are powerful weapons in the immune system! They have a regulatory role, so can suppress the immune system, ergo, dampen inflammation. 

📈This is why companies are exploiting MSCs as a cell therapy option for autoimmune diseases, graft versus host disease and organ transplant rejection. Already we have a few approved MSC products such as Prochymal, Cartistem and Temcell to name a few ! 

❤️‍🩹 MSCs are also wound healers and promote tissue repair and regeneration! This slots nicely within their immunoregulatory role ! 

⚔️Anytime you’re dealing with autoimmunity or need some wound healing, dispatch this pokeimmune.

💥 Oh and let’s not forget the obvious, MSCs have the ability to turn into different types of cells, like bone cells, cartilage or even fat cells! I think the key difference to know about MSCs is whilst they are stem cells, they have limited differentiation potential.

💫 Over the weeks the Pokédex (yes me) will release more PokeImmune cards to educate you on Immunology !

Your slightly weird immunologist xox 

#scicomm #instascience #immunology #immunity #immunecells #learnwithme

Hey guys, let’s talk about why we can’t just use data from animal studies and really need in human studies before we can execute certain protocols.

There are numerous examples where we simply don’t have findings backed up by human studies to draw conclusions on whether a protocol or drug is effective. Some examples include:
🔹Fasting to trigger autophagy
🔹 Certain Herbal remedies 
🔹 Detox diets
🔹 Supplements that are being sold with grandiose claims

🐭 Animal data is extremely informative in testing the safety and efficacy of a potential drug in a preclinical study. If we can show it’s safe and effective in the appropriate animal model, we then have the green light to file an Investigative New Drug Application to our appropriate government regulatory body, e.g. the FDA, asking for authorisation to proceed to a clinical study.

🐭 Animal research also helps inform us about certain biological processes, deciphering the role of genes and proteins. The use of transgenic models has made this even easier.

💥 However just because something has been tried and tested in animals does not mean it will be safe or work in humans.

Let’s break it down to the most obvious differences:
🔹Biological differences
🔹 Human biology is just so damn complex
🔹 Species-specific effects that will not be reflective of an in human scenario
🔹 Unexpected side effects 
🔹 Behavioural differences. 

💊 Even if we recreate the most human-like test in mice for example, using humanised mouse models and reconstituting them with human cells, there will still remain species-specific variations (from differing antigens, to even in metabolism) that will make it unreliable to extrapolate the findings for human use immediately.

💊 There’s also the caveat of finding the appropriate preclinical model for the disease. Though there are some ways of getting around this, like experimentally inducing a disease to mimic the human disease, the inability to fully replicate the disease creates challenges in drug research.

Your immunologist xox

Hey guys, I have received a number of messages asking me to cover LDN and its potential for autoimmune diseases and chronic pain treatment.

There is no surprises, that Naltrexone which is approved for alcohol and substance addiction, has been showing potential for chronic pain and autoimmunity in its low dose form. Given that this drug binds to opioid receptors, and even non-opioid receptors, on immune cells, it exerts an immunomodulatory effect. This may also be via endorphins, we’re still in the process of uncovering the details mechanistically but for now aside from binding to opioid growth factor receptors it also acts via TLR4 receptor.

At present the data for LDN has shown improvements for those with IBD, Sjögren’s syndrome, scleroderma and Rheumatoid Arthritis, with the latter showing the largest study so far. LDN has also been investigated for fibromyalgia and other chronic pain diseases. Whilst it looks good, we need higher powered studies.

 Interestingly, it’s anti inflammatory effects are being also tested in cancer. Context is key as you don’t necessarily want immunosuppression either which just shows how complex the biology is.

Stay tuned! 

Your immunologist xox

Hey guys, quick and simple reminder for you all. Although it’s tempting to interchangeably use food allergies when it’s actually an intolerance, let us remember that food intolerance is very different to food allergy. Typical signs of an intolerance is that you’ll have a gut response, whereas an allergy shows classic hallmarks of a Th2 immune response that leads to histamine and other mediator release - hives, swelling, itchiness, trouble breathing.

It’s important to note that food allergies can also present with some GI symptoms. If you suspect you’ve got a food allergy, please chat to your doctor as they can be life threatening. 

Your immunologist xox

Next up on the Pokédex, a new PokeImmune card for you to collect !

🥷 Your immune system is made up of different fighters each with their own strengths and weaknesses kind of like an army…. 
What if there was an easier way to ID them? Hey, kinda like a Pokémon card ? 🙈

🤓 I introduce you to the B cell 🔥🔥 

🧬  Let’s be honest, if there’s any cell you heard about during the last 3 years it would have been the B cell, because of the antibodies they produce!

📈 B cells are antibody factories. They can switch up which antibodies are needed depending on what they’re called up to do. For example, in the gut, your B cells will make an antibody called IgA, but in response to a parasite, your B cells will make IgE. This is called class-switching. 

⚔️B cells also undergo processes called somatic hypermutation and affinity maturation, rearranging and strengthening certain receptor combos which may be more beneficial when engaging in an attack. 

👬 What you also probably didn’t know is that B cells are also classified as an Antigen-Presenting cell (or APC), much like their comrades the Dendritic cell and Macrophage, which hopefully you have already collected in your Pokeimmune deck (scroll on my page to find them!). As an APC, the B cell alerts T cell of invading pathogens.

👭 B cells and T cells also need each other. B cells needs T cells signals to fully activate and do their job.

Hi guys. This is probably my most important post in a while. Regression to the mean is a statistical phenomenon taken seriously in the medical and scientific and so you should learn about it too as it’s a cognitive illusion - alternative therapies enters the chat.
If you measure a variable on two separate occasions and one of those values is extreme, it’s likely to be closer to the average on the occasion that wasn’t extreme. 
I hope this post is self explanatory but comment below and let’s chat. 
Most importantly, share this post to educate your friends.

Your immunologist xox

I’ve discussed in a previous post why “boosting” the immune system is a highly complicated proof of concept. Maybe it shouldn’t be, if you know what activates immune cells - like T cells - why not just infuse a molecule that will simply switch on that activator? 

That’s what happened in the TGN1412 disaster. Read on 👇🏼

🚨Now before I discuss the TGN1412 trial let’s please be clear that many immunotherapy related trials have been successful and are currently underway - including a trial that my company have rolled out and I’m working hard on ( BASECAMP-1 and EVEREST-1 if you’re curious!). But all these trials have been designed to ensure patient safety is priority… 

💊 The TGN1412 trial conducted in 2006 tested a super T cell activator (called CD28 superagonist) to assess its suitability for cancer and autoimmunity.
💊 6 healthy volunteers enrolled. Within 90 mins , all 6 were in intensive care and developing multi organ failure. They all had a Cytokine Storm (or CRS)
💊 Don’t worry, they all survived but narrowly tbh (and some missing fingertips and toes….).

Now the TGN1412 trial was a disaster for a number of reasons as it gained global attention and regulators sought to figure out what on Earth happened. 
For one, a pretty daft idea to infuse a first-of-it’s-kind immunotherapy into 6 patients in one go, that’s not how clinical trials should be done nor are done now. The other being not modulating the drug product between pre-clinical to clinical. 

The purpose of this post is to highlight, however, that a basic eureka moment of infusing patients with a CD28 superagonist was not going to yield a solution to a very complicated problem with a complex interplay of mechanisms and processes in the body. 

This can also apply to extracts or compounds in your favourite supplements that “may have cancer fighting properties” like in your CBD or antioxidant pill. If it’s not been shown to do so, don’t claim it, it’s more complicated than that, and may even yield undesirable effects as has been seen in high doses of antioxidant studies - okay maybe not CRS. 

Your immunologist xox

I contemplated a longer post to give a breakdown of why leaky gut syndrome is given the credibility it has by non experts, and it’s relationship to autoimmunity and GI diseases but it’s better to keep it simple - otherwise I risk giving the term actual credibility.

We can recognise a “leaky gut” or increased gut permeability has a relationship with such diseases. Some experts may be more forgiving of using the term “leaky gut” to explain increased gut permeability. 

The problem is when you are told it is an actual disease or syndrome itself, and that it is the root cause of all your issues.

Use “leaky gut syndrome” to be your litmus test for bs accounts on here trying to educate you.

Your immunologist xox

Fun fact Tuesday for you all. When reading about the antioxidant diets and fads recently , I couldn’t help but make a post to say hey free radicals aren’t always a bad thing in your body. Let’s be clear, it’s all about a balance. If you have uncontrolled build up of free radicals in the body, though it’s not the sole cause, they definitely do contribute to disease in the body. This is why we have mechanisms in the body to mop up free radicals. 
But thought I’d remind you of the times where free radicals are useful 😗.

Your immunologist xox

I haven’t showed you guys a fancy CAR T cell killing a cancer cell in a while!
This time it’s a CAR T cell that has been modified to distinguish a healthy cell from a cancerous cell!

🔸 CAR T cell therapy has revolutionised the immunotherapy space.

🔸But one of the problems with generating a cell therapy product against cancer cells is the need to identify a target that only cancer cells express and not healthy cells.

🔸 There are some which the CAR T cell space are already generating clinical products for.

🔸 Or in some cases the risk of wiping out all the healthy cells isn’t such a bad thing - like the leukaemia CAR T cells that wipe out all B cells; not a huge deal, they all come back.

🔸This is an example of a new type of CAR T cell tech, called Tmod, where the CAR T cell has learned to tell apart a healthy cell from a cancer cell ! 

🔸 Tumour cell is in green, healthy cell is in red

🚨🚨 Disclaimer alert, I work for this company, my opinions are my own and do not reflect that of the company; this page is my personal page and a separate entity;  this isn’t a plug or promo (I’d be in big trouble if it was!!). I just think the tech is so flipping cool, which is the reason I joined in the first place, so I wanted to show you all how badass my job is 😍🎉.

But the response should not be turning to predatory quacks and alternative therapists who use methods or protocols that are not evidence-based. The only reason this reel should aggravate you is because I used a Nickelback track. 

There’s a few topics I wanted to address with this reel.

1️⃣ One of the biggest frustrations is being told people have done their own research for years on a topic. They show me scientific papers to back up their views. Firstly, I could touch on “publication bias” from the authors, where they had a hypothesis, stuck to their guns and were determined to show only data that backed their views. Non experts may struggle to smell a rat, but those who are in the specific field may be more likely to sniff out missing data.

2️⃣ The other issue here is the researchers themselves are possibly at risk of a bias, specifically searching for any papers that fit their findings. If you type “can XXX cure cancer” you may possibly find a paper on it and use it to back your views.

🚨 Unfortunately this is how you can tease out those who can science and those who can’t science on social media. There may be some genuinely well-intended accounts on here that will say “did you know ABC can help your symptoms?” And flash up a paper title. If you read the paper, the methodology is questionable, the sampling is poor and the interpretation of the results is unbalanced. Only someone practicing within the field for many years, who has authored scientific papers and has conducted such experiments for themselves will be able to tell, unfortunately. 

This is why we say leave it to the experts to tell you if a study is good and trust their judgement. Which leads me to the third point.. 

3️⃣ Scientists do not receive marching orders from some sort of authority on how we should think. We think for ourselves, and actually we typically sit on the side of acute scepticism and scrutiny when reading potentially controversial papers. Having a healthy level of scepticism is important , it doesn’t mean we dismiss your thoughts on a paper you stumbled across. 

Of course there may be some scientists or medics with a conflict of interest, but they will (and should) state it always on a publication.

Got thoughts, comments, potential rants? Even if it’s that you hate nickelback? Comment below 👇🏼👀

I think it’s important to remember that this remains the dogma until we arrive at more concrete conclusions. There is no doubt that Vitamin D, zinc and magnesium for example play important roles in the immune system - as do others! The benefits are more pronounced when you’re deficient, however. It’s easier for most to be deficient in Vitamin D for example and supplementation here is key, versus zinc or magnesium.
As for selenium, there are links to its potential thyroid supporting role especially those with Hashimotos, however the date remains inconsistent and inconclusive for now. 

Take home message is ensure you’re not deficient, don’t make supplementation your first priority over good nutrition, sleep, stress management and exercise. 

Your fellow Hashi warrior xox

Viruses in general are linked to developing autoimmune diseases. There’s nothing chill about that and you’re not hard as nails for powering through if you’re sick - you actually put yourself at higher risk of post viral complications like autoimmunity.

Here it is, the link between covid and autoimmune diseases.

Please know that cryptic antigens are a sub-mechanism of epitope spreading. 

The development of autoimmunity is complicated and involves genetic components, however viral-induced autoimmunity is a very well established phenomenon. 

Your immunologist xo

🌍 In November 2018, scientists woke up to the news that twin baby girls had been born in China with DNA edited when they were embryos. News broke that another parent was also pregnant with a third edited baby 🧬

🧬 The Scientist behind the feat is He Jiankui. This was the first germline editing performed on human embryos, these edits can be passed on from one generation to the next.

🚨 This was reckless, immoral, unethical and ILLEGAL 💥💥

🧬 He Jiankui used CRISPR to edit out the CCR5 gene in the non-identical embryos. The CCR5 gene encodes for an immune cell receptor that is one of the entry routes for HIV to infect a cell.

🧬He was attempting to make these babies immune from catching HIV in their lifetime.

👩🏻‍⚖️ From an ethical standpoint, we can discuss genome editing when 1️⃣ there is an unmet need, i.e. there is no other solution to save someone’s life, 2️⃣ the risk of not doing so outweighs the risk of performing such a procedure. And more….

💥💥This is not classified as an “unmet need”. There are other ways to prevent yourself from getting HIV, from passing HIV down to a child if a parent is positive, but most critical of all, this will NOT guarantee no HIV – CXCR4 is yet another receptor HIV uses to infect cells.

🧬 He Jiankui’s attempt at surprising the world in November 2018 was met with global condemnation & criticism. It seemed that He was absolutely clueless as to why there was such a global outrage, and more of a case of extreme naivety.

🧬China responded aggressively condemning He Jiankui’s experiment such that he was thrown into prison.

🧬 There was a lot of blaming on who knew of He’s experiments and did not raise alarm bells.

🧬The twin girls’ parents apparently were informed of the risks and what they were consenting to. Whether they knew the depths remains up for debate. But clearly, He did not obtain ethical approval (duh, it’s illegal). 

🍼 The twin girls, Nana and Lulu are apparently well and living in complete privacy in China, however they are mosaic babies – the genes were not completely edited nor correctly.

📚If you want to learn more, I highly recommend “CRISPR People by Henry T Greely”.

The disconnect between scientists and the public has always been present but becomes amplified during waves of epidemics or pandemics : examples like smallpox, cholera, HIV and the Vid. 

Scientists have a moral duty to educate the public and resolve the dissonance. However I have come to understand that those with good intentions (like me, I said it) try and do so, we get doxxed, threats and serious accusations which make us realise it’s better to just not engage with the public at all and continue to only better the field by engaging with our peers. 

Which leads to more accusations and the cycle begins again. Stop dehumanising us.

Do better on here, as I and my fellow scientists will. Ask, engage in challenging conversations, frame questions in a respectful but curious way. If you lobby insults and accusations you’ll continue to be apart of the problem that has lead to this dissonance.

Signed, a pissed off scientist xox

In case you didn’t know! There are many reasons why our immune systems differ from lads, from hormones to even the X chromosome possessing most of the immune genes! 

 The major differences were most interesting during the Vid, as in the first wave of the disease it was mostly elderly men who succumbed - and groups began looking at whether testosterone was a driver.

Did you learn something new or have some thoughts 💭? Comment below and let’s chat 👇🏼👇🏼

Many people online act as though alternative strategies are more helpful for cancer patients than modern therapeutic strategies.
.
However, what we have found through RESEARCH into specific alternative strategies for cancer is that they can be complimentary to traditional treatments. We have also found that opting out of chemotherapies, immunotherapies, radiotherapies and others for alternative therapies decreases likelihoods of patient survival (PMID: 28922780).
.
We know that alternative therapies that employ specific supplements, behavioral therapy, and diet strategies may improve patient quality of life. For example, THC derivatives are used to help with nausea, vitamins are used to help with bone and muscle loss, and some diets are even used to enhance responses to chemotherapies/ immunotherapies.
.
However, most alternative strategies do not currently have enough evidence to be singular treatments for cancers. 
.
Both Yas and I know that cancer is a scary diagnosis and can stress people into making decisions that aren’t evidence based. We are here to help provide evidence for cancer treatments, where applicable, to inform you all as unbiased as we possibly can.
.
The truth is, cancer isn’t a simple disease to treat… no disease is. While we wish alternative therapies were enough to treat cancers, they are insufficient alone. In fact, they can even counteract modern medicines. This being said, you need to be honest with your doctors about any alternative therapies you are trying to get the most out of your treatment options.
.
We still have A LOT to learn about how diets and supplements affect tumor metabolism. I’m hopeful for ongoing clinical trials, but until they’re finished with sufficient patient data I cannot provide strong advice about diet strategies for most cancers.
.
Be careful where you get your info and think critically about the info you are receiving.
.
Ask questions below 👇

And that’s a wrap! And what a year it’s been for science !! As a scientist myself working in the cancer space I got to reach some personal triumphs as we entered our first clinical trial for patients with pancreatic, colorectal, lung and now ovarian cancer 🥳. 
Here are my top 5 breakthroughs of 2023 🍾🍾!

1️⃣ The first EVER CRISPR Gene editing treatment was approved for Sickle Cell Anaemia. This is a huge milestone for the gene editing world as CRISPR gained interest for its applications in editing genes in 2012. Sickle cell disease is an excruciatingly painful disease as haemoglobin (in red blood cells) are shaped like a sickle and can lead to organ damage.

2️⃣ Let’s talk about Lecanemab, the Alzheimer’s treatment that got approved this year. It’s an antibody treatment that binds to amyloid-beta build up, slowing the progression of the disease. Now some consider this a controversial pick as Lecanemab seems to show only a modest improvement and uncertain longterm improvements when we consider cost-benefit ratio. 

3️⃣ Drugs mimicking GLP-1 like Ozempic or Wegovy are diabetes drugs and were approved to treat obesity. This year however, these drugs made headlines due to new results showing reduced risk of cardiovascular disease and kidney disease! There’s even talks about trying them against Alzheimer’s and Parkinson’s due to the effects in the brain.

4️⃣ Okay this one is not one specific breakthrough but I wanted to draw attention to the way AI is taking over the protein engineering space. AlphaFold gained attention 2 years ago, but now we’re seeing AI and ML improve with precision and accuracy at a scary rate that it’s applications to medicine are going to reshape drug discovery. I would advise everyone on here to educate yourselves further on AI /ML and protein engineering as these are the next phase of R&D.

5️⃣ The best for last 👀, Narcan got approved this year as the first over-the-counter naloxone nasal spray that can reverse opioid overdose in minutes !! We need strategies to contain the opioid epidemic and this was a huge step towards reducing drug overdose.

Cheers 2023 🍾, bring on 2024 🥳✨

Your immunologist xox

Hey guys, let’s discuss this scary headline that rocked the medical and scientific community.

💬 Like 👉🏼save 👉🏼 share this reel ! Comment below and let’s discuss your thoughts on this video.
📲 Don’t forget to hit that follow button for more science content!

🧬 I think the key thing to discuss here is that this was never something unexpected and even the FDA do inform patients that there is always a small risk that this could happen. This is due to the method that we deliver the CAR into patients T cells in the lab, viral vector transduction. 

🧬This is a very well established technique, the only downside is that where the CAR DNA integrates is random within our DNA. This is usually fine, but on occasions it can integrate in a place that it shouldn’t, and possibly transform a cell into a cancer cell.

🧬 I think even more critically to note is that the benefits far outweigh the risks. Unfortunately cancer treatment regimens such as chemotherapy or radiotherapy also introduce a risk of developing secondary cancers later on down the line, so the risk with immunotherapy is definitely lower.

👩🏻‍🔬 What scientist like us need to do is to develop new ways of creating life-saving treatments that mitigate such a risk. 

💥CRISPR or mRNA are two such methods I have suggested but they are still very much in their infancy and bring their own challenges when manufacturing, this is why we prefer to stick with viral vectors which are very well established in the industry.

What are your thoughts? I’d love to hear from you. Comment below and let’s chat 💬 👇🏼.

Your immunologist xox

https://doi.org/10.1038/s41591-023-02767-w

Good morning team, today let’s discuss about what being immunocompromised actually means. This may have been a confusing one especially as of the events of the last few years, so I thought I would bring clarity to what is known at the moment.

Interestingly enough, I had a conversation recently with a follower who says that in the hospital they even classify those for type 1 diabetes as being immunocompromised. Furthermore, I actually was bumped up the list during the pandemic to get the 🥕 because in my GP’s system I was registered as being immunocompromised with my Hashimoto’s. All this kind of surprised me.

We are still learning more about how autoimmune diseases can directly impact immunity, however the rule of thumb is unless if your autoimmune disease requires you to be on some sort of immunosuppressive medication, you are not technically classified as immunocompromised.

Got questions? I would love to discuss this and hear what your views are! Comment below and let’s chat 👇🏼.

Your immunologist xox
